political: Today, Peter Schiefke and I hosted an Instagram Live on the Leaders Today account to talk with young Canadians about the new Canada Service Corps. Thanks to everyone who joined us to share their experiences and what it means to serve our communities. But we want to hear from more of you! Head over to canada.ca/canadaservicecorps and let us know what matters to you most and how you want to build a better community, and a better country, through service. https://www.facebook.com/JustinPJTrudeau/

New jobs numbers are out: Unemployment is at 5.7% - the lowest since the Labour Force Survey began in 1976. Congratulations Canadians! Your hard work is paying off - and we’re going to keep working for you. Even more: In 2017, Canada’s economy added 422K jobs. That’s the most in a year since 2002. Overall, the economy created about 700K new jobs since our government took office. Alberta and Quebec led the way in job creation last month – and Quebec’s unemployment rate is now the lowest on record. We know the monthly numbers come and go – that’s why we’re focused on a long-term plan to create jobs, strengthen the middle class, and give Canadian families the support they need. #RealChangeIsWorking 🇨🇦 https://www.facebook.com/JustinPJTrudeau/
Happy New Year! I’m looking forward to what we can accomplish together in 2018: https://www.facebook.com/JustinPJTrudeau/
Bonne Année ! Je me réjouis de ce que nous allons accomplir ensemble en 2018 : https://www.facebook.com/JustinPJTrudeau/
This was a good start, but we know there’s more to do. We’re committed to ending them all by 2021. https://www.facebook.com/JustinPJTrudeau/

Today’s report from the Conflict of Interest and Ethics Commissioner makes it very clear that I should have cleared my family vacation and dealings with the Aga Khan in advance. I’m sorry I didn’t, and in the future I’ll be clearing all family vacations with the Commissioner’s office. I’ve always considered the Aga Khan a close family friend – that’s why I didn’t clear this family trip in the first place. Given the Commissioner’s report, I’ll be taking all precautions in the future. https://www.facebook.com/JustinPJTrudeau/

As a diverse nation, Canada is enriched by the lives, experiences, and contributions of all LGBTQ2 Canadians. Today, on behalf of the government, Parliament, and the people of Canada, I delivered an official apology for Canada’s role in the systemic oppression, criminalization, and violence against the LGBTQ2 community. https://www.facebook.com/JustinPJTrudeau/

Le Canada, en tant que nation à la population diversifiée, est enrichi par les vies, les expériences et les contributions de tous les Canadiens LGBTQ2. Aujourd’hui, au nom du gouvernement, du Parlement et du peuple canadiens, j’ai présenté des excuses officielles pour le rôle qu’a joué le Canada dans l’oppression systémique de la communauté LGBTQ2 ainsi que la criminalisation et les violences qu’elle a subies. https://www.facebook.com/JustinPJTrudeau/

Today, in the House of Commons on behalf of the Government of Canada, I offer my sincerest apologies to LGBTQ2 Canadians for the oppression and injustices they have suffered. Watch live: Aujourd’hui, à la Chambre des communes au nom du gouvernement du Canada, j’offre mes excuses les plus sincères aux Canadiens LGBTQ2 qui ont souffert de l’oppression et des injustices. Nous sommes ravis d’annoncer que le PLC(O) tiendra son école de campagne et réunion d’établissement des priorités politiques du PLC(O) le 4 novembre 2017 à Toronto. L’école de campagne du PLC(O) donne l’occasion aux libéraux de peaufiner leurs techniques de campagne tout en partageant leur propre expérience, alors que nous nous préparons à l’élection générale de 2019. Après des mois de consultation de la base sur les politiques à l’échelle de la province, le réunion d’établissement des priorités politiques du PLC(O) nous donnera l’occasion de nous rassembler pour définir nos priorités pour l’avenir.Cet événement s’adresse à tous les libéraux inscrits. https://www.facebook.com/LPCO.PLCO/

We are excited to announce that the LPC(O) will be will be holding its 2017 Campaign College and Policy Prioritization Meeting in Toronto on November 4th, 2017. The LPC(O) Campaign College will provide an opportunity for Liberals to expand their campaigning skills, as well as an opportunity to share their own experiences as we prepare for the 2019 General Election. After months of grassroots policy consultation across the province the Policy Prioritization Meeting will bring us together to shape our priorities moving forward. Please note you must be a Registered Liberal to attend. https://www.facebook.com/LPCO.PLCO/

Today is #ThursdayTalks with LPC(O) and we'd like to introduce you to David de Paiva!"I believe in the Liberal Party of Canada because I believe in equity, positivity and reconciliation. I believe in my fellow Canadians, and I believe in a future where all Canadians, regardless of their ethnicity, gender or sexual orientation, have a voice. Also, I was told this was where the people with nice hair belonged." https://www.facebook.com/LPCO.PLCO/

Today is #ThursdayTalks with LPC(O) and we'd like to introduce you to Marco Puddu! (pictured far left)"Not so long ago; during the years leading up to, and the year of our 2015 general election I, among many others realized I wasn’t satisfied with the current state of affairs in our political landscape, and that there were changes that needed to be made. With this dissatisfaction as a recurring thought in my mind, I worked towards becoming properly informed and yet found it wanting. I knew that it wasn’t enough to just be informed and that if I wanted to see real change, I would have to lead by example. So I began to volunteer with the Liberal Party of Canada. Through working with people that I truly and full-heartedly support and believe in, I found myself finally able to play that part in helping to work towards the positive changes I had hoped to see. One of my favourite parts about working in politics is seeing such things come together so well. No matter what you’re trying to do; when you see that your work and that of others has come together harmoniously to achieve something great-it is an immensely proud moment." https://www.facebook.com/LPCO.PLCO/

Today is #ThursdayTalks with LPC(O) and we'd like to introduce you to Colin Mahovlich!"I’ve always retained a passion for politics and firmly believe a healthy country requires a healthy amount of political participation from all members of society. Time and time again I’m amazed at the dedication of many of the MP’s I’ve spoken too, being able to hear out their informed perspectives, and clearly seeing the drive to do what’s right. The responsibility to hear peoples concerns and to find practical solutions aimed at getting results continues to drive me to participate in political life. I strongly believe it’s important to fight the cynicism that many people slide into when they fail to see results from the actions of their leaders. The Liberal Party continues to lead Canada in a positive direction and focuses on delivering those tangible results on the issues I care about." https://www.facebook.com/LPCO.PLCO/
Check out what Canadians from across the country are saying about the difference the Canada Child Benefit is making in their lives: https://www.facebook.com/LPCO.PLCO/

Today is #ThursdayTalks with LPC(O) and today we'd like to introduce you to Haseeb Hassaan!"I came to Canada from Sri Lanka at a young age, I am thankful to immigrate to a beautiful country that was diverse, open and accepting of people from different backgrounds. The Liberal Party of Canada is one of the main reasons for this, it has been at the forefront of the issues that I hold dear. I know there is a lot of work still to be done and I think the Liberal Party of Canada is the best avenue for the change that I want to see in the world. This is why I’m a Liberal." https://www.facebook.com/LPCO.PLCO/

Policy decisions were happening that went against scientific evidence and that would clearly marginalise certain groups and supported specific ideologies. I was able to start attending events without any pressure to join. I got to meet great people and found people with whom I shared many values and aspirations for how Canada could be so much better. Since then, it's been my great pleasure to work with my local Liberal riding association to engage our community members and grow the Liberal brand. For Hotblack Coffee co-owner Jimson Bienenstock, supporting his workers by increasing their wages is a win-win. Not only is it good for them, it’s also good for his business. When his staff are paid a living wage, team morale gets a boost, and that means less turnover for Jimson’s business. And when it comes down to it, keeping customers coming back is about more than good coffee — a happy team leads to happy customers.We’ll keep fighting for fairness for workers, and listening to businesses big and small across the province, so that our economy can continue to thrive. https://www.facebook.com/WynneFans/

I’m reading comments on this page about increased child care costs due to the minimum wage. I’m working to keep costs down with special funding for child care centres to deal with increased costs. I know parents agree, people who care for our children should earn a living wage. When kids get the best possible start in life, everyone wins — now and in the future. That’s why we’re continuing to invest in new schools and child care spaces in communities throughout Ontario. Parents tell me they’re struggling to find convenient, quality child care close to home. Licensed child care spaces in schools will provide families with access to care in a place that’s convenient, and help with the transition to kindergarten, too. Modern learning environments and more licensed child care spaces will help kids get the best start in life.https://news.ontario.ca/edu/en/2018/01/new-schools-and-child-care-spaces-coming-to-communities-across-ontario.html https://www.facebook.com/WynneFans/

At HotBlack Coffee, paying staff a fair, living wage gives the team the boost they need to live better lives. It’s simple: when employees make enough to take care of themselves and their families, everyone wins. People used to think that minimum wage jobs were only for students, but the reality is that more and more people are working 40-hour weeks at minimum wage to support themselves. I believe workers should make enough to afford the basics for themselves and their families. It’s time to give workers across Ontario the fair, living wage they deserve. https://www.facebook.com/WynneFans/

Listening to people is one of the most important parts of my job. That’s why I’m holding Town Halls all over Ontario. I need to hear from you about the challenges you face, and what the government can do to help.My next Town Hall will be this Thursday, January 18, in Ottawa. Please join me and bring your questions or whatever’s on your mind — no topic will be off the table. RSVP here to let me know you’ll be there: https://www.ontario.ca/form/ontario-town-hall-ottawa https://www.facebook.com/WynneFans/

I am deeply troubled to hear reports this morning that a young woman at Pauline Johnson Public School was repeatedly and violently attacked for wearing her hijab to school today. This is a cowardly act of hatred, and it has no place in Ontario. The alleged actions of the one man suspected of perpetrating this heinous act in no way represent who we are. It is by collectively condemning acts of violence and hatred such as this that we show who we really are in Ontario.We must stand firm in our support for this young girl and her community, and in speaking out against racism and intolerance in every form. Everyone in our province has the right to worship and dress however they choose. And everyone has the right to feel safe and respected no matter what they are wearing or where they go.If the reports we are hearing are accurate, this can only be seen as an attempt to make certain people feel unwelcome or unsafe in our province. We will not stand for it. Everyone belongs in Ontario and everyone should be able to safely express themselves and their beliefs. https://www.facebook.com/WynneFans/

“We want each of you to know that we do not resent having to provide this increase as you are all absolutely worth it,” Jeff Knoll, CEO of an independent theatre in Oakville, wrote to his employees about raising the minimum wage to $14. It’s fantastic to see support for workers. People deserve a living wage for the hard work they do every day. The truth is, when people are paid fairly, everyone wins. A living wage leads to greater job satisfaction and productivity, less turnover and more spending power for workers. When workers have more money, businesses have more customers and hire more workers. There’s no denying that that’s good for everyone. I’ll keep listening to businesses and taking actions to address their concerns about raising the minimum wage. But I will not apologize for doing what’s right for workers, and I won’t ever stop fighting for fairness. https://www.facebook.com/WynneFans/

I’m fighting for workers by increasing the minimum wage. But I’ve also been fighting for Ontario workers in other ways. As the official start of the NAFTA negotiations approached, I’ve taken every opportunity to defend Ontario workers. I have met with dozens of mayors, governors, senators and other leaders from all levels of government across the U.S. I’ve traveled to Washington, D.C. to talk about a renewed NAFTA as an opportunity to create fairness and growth on both sides of the border.  I’m happy to hear that GM will be producing a new line of trucks in Oshawa. The is good news for the workers there. Oshawa has a strong history in auto production — they’ve been part of the industry for over 100 years. I’m going to keep fighting for the workers there, and across Ontario. https://www.facebook.com/WynneFans/

You don’t have to look very far online or in the news today to see workers speaking in support of increasing the minimum wage. Increasing the minimum wage to $14 was the right thing to do for those trying to support their families. Minister of Labour Kevin Flynn was at Yorkdale Shopping Centre in Toronto over the holidays to speak with workers — 55% of Ontario’s retail workers got a raise on January 1st — and I’ve spoken with workers in the New Year who tell me the boost in income will make a huge difference. I’m committed to fighting for workers across the province by raising the minimum wage again to $15 next year. https://www.facebook.com/WynneFans/

Increasing the minimum wage was long overdue for the hardworking people of Ontario. Simply put, it is the right thing to do for our workers, especially now that Ontario’s growth is outperforming all G7 countries. I understand the pressure this change puts on some small business owners. But a growing number of them are saying that paying their staff a living wage is good for business. A father of six who runs a metal parts processing facility in Niagara and a millennial entrepreneur with a dog walking business may not have much in common, but they agree on this: the benefits of paying people a living wage outweigh the costs. https://www.facebook.com/WynneFans/

I’ve already heard from parents who say it’s making a difference for them. Based on what parents are telling me, I know, for the millions of parents who were struggling to afford the medication their kids need, or simply couldn’t afford to foot the bill out of pocket, OHIP+ is going to make a huge difference. The biggest expansion to medicare in a generation took effect on January 1st and provides free prescription medication for everyone under 25. All you need is a health card. It was such a necessary expansion, not just for parents, but for youth and new graduates, too.  OHIP+ is a great start, but as Dr. Jessica Ross points out, it’s not enough. It’s past time for a national universal pharmacare plan. As we build a province that is fair and full of opportunity for everyone, I will absolutely continue to push the federal government to implement a universal pharmacare plan that benefits not just the people of Ontario, but all Canadians. https://www.facebook.com/WynneFans/

You don’t have to talk to many workers before it becomes clear that a minimum wage increase was long overdue. I’ve made my stance on this clear — raising the minimum wage is the right thing to do for Ontario workers. And overwhelmingly I’m hearing from workers that they also believe this is the right thing to do. We raised the minimum wage to $14 to create more fairness and opportunity in our province, but now unfortunately it appears that some employers are abandoning the spirit of this legislation and some may even be doing worse than that. The stories we've all heard over the past week have not only been disappointing, but quite frankly, they've made me and others in this province angry. Working people in Ontario deserve much better than that. I understand the pressure raising the minimum wage will put on some business owners, but as my colleague Kevin Flynn, the Minister of Labour, said this morning, the bullying behaviour we’ve seen from some businesses will not be tolerated.To Ontario workers, I say this: We've got your backs. The vast majority of businesses in this province are decent organizations that understand that if they treat their employees well, they become more profitable, and they become more productive. Nobody working 40 hours a week should have to live in poverty. That simply isn't on in Ontario. We've made changes that will protect and support you and will make our workplaces fair for everyone. https://www.facebook.com/WynneFans/

Kids like Rayanna give me so much hope for the future. This 10-year-old I met at my Town Hall in Brampton has so many thoughtful ideas about how we can build a better province — and world — for everyone. And she’s not shy about sharing them! I can’t wait to see what she accomplishes. https://www.facebook.com/WynneFans/

This was a big week for fairness in Ontario! On January 1st, changes came into effect to make Ontario a more fair and decent place to work. You’ve probably heard that the minimum wage was raised to $14 an hour, but there were other changes, too: all workers now get 3 weeks’ paid vacation after 5 years with the same employer, everyone gets personal emergency leave to handle life’s ups and downs, and we’ve increased parental leave, too. The changes don’t stop here. The biggest one yet will take place next January 1, 2019, when the minimum wage gets another boost to $15. Until then, and after, I’ll continue working to make Ontario a fairer, better province for everyone. https://www.facebook.com/WynneFans/

Mental illness should be treated like any other illness — and treated with the same fast access to care that we provide when someone gets sick. But unfortunately, those supports just aren’t there yet — and they’re especially needed for youth. Last year when I spoke with students on school campuses across Ontario, one of the topics that came up the most often was mental health. Students of all ages shared their mental health struggles with me. Young people today are so intelligent and capable, but they still need our support. That’s why in 2017 Ontario invested in more psychotherapy, supportive housing, and mental health services for youth. With faster access to mental health and addictions services, thousands more young people can access the support they need, when they need it. https://www.facebook.com/WynneFans/

Aisha Abdunnur, a 21-year-old woman from Ottawa recently told Chatelaine the minimum wage increase “will change my life because, hopefully, I won’t be constantly worried.” For Aisha and her family, the increase is being able to afford “basic things”. The time to increase the minimum wage is now. In 2017 Ontario added more than 175,000 jobs. Big businesses continue to celebrate record profits, while many people in this province still can’t afford the basics.Ron Joyce Jr. — a man whose family founded the Tim Hortons chain, which was sold for billions of dollars — wrote a letter to his employees stating those who want to continue receiving dental and health benefits will have to pay a portion of the plan’s costs.Workers at a Tim Hortons in Eastern Ontario have been asked to sign a pledge agreeing to work nine hours and be paid for eight and agreeing to lose their health benefits. I must admit, I was deeply upset to read these reports.I’ll be blunt. It is the act of a bully.If Mr. Joyce wants to pick a fight, I urge him to pick it with me and not those working the pickup window and service counter of his stores.It’s past time we put people ahead of profits. That’s why I am so disheartened when I hear some of the wealthiest among us want to offset this much-needed raise on the backs of their employees.Tim Hortons is a Canadian institution. It’s a ritual before Saturday morning hockey and a daily habit many of us enjoy. But I know I want the person who hands me a tea or coffee in the morning to be able to pay their bills, raise his or her kids and enjoy the full benefits of life in Ontario. Again, I think that’s just fair — and I know many people across this province agree.Please see my Op-Ed in today’s Toronto Star: https://www.thestar.com/opinion/contributors/2018/01/05/pick-a-fight-with-me-mr-joyce-not-those-working-the-pickup-window.html https://www.facebook.com/WynneFans/

Increasing the minimum wage is for the families who work 40+ hour weeks but still need to go to the food bank to put food on the table for their kids; it’s for the single parents who work multiple jobs to make ends meet; and it’s for everyone working hard but still unable to get ahead.  It’s going to change lives. And so, like many others I was upset to read reports about how Ron Joyce Jr – a man whose family founded the Tim Horton’s chain which was sold for billions of dollars – is treating his employees and responding to the recent rise in the minimum wage. The many people who get up and put in a full day’s work in this province deserve to be paid decently and, just as importantly, they deserve to be treated decently. Asking workers to sign a pledge agreeing to unpaid breaks or agreeing to less pay than actual hours worked is neither decent nor fair.I’ll be blunt. It is the act of a bully. I’ve always fought for those who are being treated unfairly and I’m not about to stop now – so if Mr. Joyce wants to pick a fight, I urge him to pick it with me and not those working the pick-up window and service counter of his stores. https://www.facebook.com/WynneFans/

Ontario is growing faster than all G7 countries, which is fantastic news, but that growth means the cost of buying or renting a home has gone up, too. High housing prices, especially in the Greater Golden Horseshoe, are pushing families out of the market. We needed to take action to make renting or buying home in Ontario more affordable, and that’s exactly what our plan is doing. https://www.facebook.com/WynneFans/

Raising the minimum wage to $14 an hour (which took effect on Monday!) is going to change lives and it puts fairness at the heart of Ontario’s growing economy. For the third straight year, Ontario is outperforming all G7 countries in growth, and our unemployment rate is the lowest it’s been in 17 years. BUT - and it’s a big but - even with all this positive news there are still so many families who are getting left behind in our rapidly changing economy. The rich are getting richer. Something needs to be done to make sure ordinary families can get ahead. And that’s why we’re taking bold, decisive action to rebalance the scales. We’ve just made the biggest increase to the minimum wage in Ontario history. Next year we’re bringing more fairness by boosting the minimum wage even further to $15 on January 1, 2019. The Conservatives still want to stop that from happening. But I still know that raising the minimum wage to $14 then $15 an hour is the right thing to do. https://www.facebook.com/WynneFans/

Creig says OHIP+ means he won’t have to worry about the cost of his son’s prescription medication anymore. That’s a load off his mind and pocket.The New Year means free pharmacare for children and youth under 25 and we'll keep fighting to deliver the best health care for everyone in Ontario. Happy New Year. https://www.facebook.com/WynneFans/
OHIP+ started in the New Year. It means free prescription medication for kids and youth under 25. https://www.facebook.com/WynneFans/

The minimum wage in Ontario is now $14! Hard-working families across the province deserve a fair living wage, and today we’re making that happen. This is for the families who work 40+ hour weeks but still need to go to the food bank to put food on the table for their kids; it’s for the single parents who work multiple jobs to make ends meet; and it’s for everyone working hard but still unable to get ahead. In our changing economy, we’re taking action to make sure that everyone has good opportunities and a fair shot at success, so we’re not stopping here. The minimum wage will increase again — this time to $15 — on January 1, 2019. https://www.facebook.com/WynneFans/

Happy New Year! We’re starting 2018 off right — with positive changes for Ontario workers. Take a look to see the changes that are taking effect today to make Ontario fairer. https://www.facebook.com/WynneFans/
Wishing you all the best in the year ahead! With several landmark changes lined up for Ontario, I think 2018 is going to be a great year. https://www.facebook.com/WynneFans/

Tomorrow is the big day! I’ve been talking about how we’re taking action to make a positive difference for people in Ontario, and tomorrow we’ll take one of the biggest steps. The minimum wage is increasing to $14 at midnight! Our economy is changing, and more and more people are struggling to support themselves and their family on minimum-wage work. Increasing the minimum wage to $14 tomorrow, and $15 by January 1, 2019, will give more than a quarter of employees across the province a much-needed and much-deserved wage hike. https://www.facebook.com/WynneFans/

In just a few days, we’re launching the biggest expansion of health care in Ontario in a generation. 4,400 prescription drugs will become absolutely free for everyone 24 and under through OHIP+. This will make a huge difference for millions of kids and their families across the province. And it’s just the beginning.I’m committed to fighting for a universal pharmacare program for everyone in the province, and by making prescriptions free for everyone under 25, we’ve taken a big step forward. There is no program like this anywhere in Canada. One day soon, I hope we can have a national pharmacare program from coast to coast to coast. With Ontario’s leadership, that day could come soon. https://www.facebook.com/WynneFans/

As Premier, some decisions are difficult to make. But sometimes, the need for action is crystal clear. Electricity is an essential part of our daily lives, and for too long, governments (mine included) had made mistakes in the way we structured Ontario’s electricity system. The system became unreliable and it was poisoning our air. We fixed it, but it was a mistake to put all those costs on just today’s generation of ratepayers. They should have been spread out over the life of the system. Cutting hydro rates by 25% earlier this year was the right thing to do. Ontario is a fairer place because of it. https://www.facebook.com/WynneFans/

Building a fairer, better Ontario is about creating the conditions where everyone has a chance to get ahead — and stay ahead. Because right now, the rich are getting richer but everyone else is barely able to keep up. And if you’ve fallen on hard times, hard work alone is no guarantee you’ll get back on your feet. You need a real chance. That’s what the Basic Income pilot we launched this year is giving people in communities around the province — the support they need to take care of themselves, retrain or find a job, and get back on their feet. And if it works the way we hope, we’ll look at scaling it up. We can’t escape a changing global economy, but by changing the way we do things in Ontario, we absolutely can come through this period of upheaval into more opportunity, more security and more fairness. https://www.facebook.com/WynneFans/

This one is making a big difference for hundreds of thousands of students and their families: we’ve overhauled OSAP so that more students have the opportunity to go to college or university — regardless of their family’s income — and graduate with less debt. To compete and succeed in our global economy, we need our graduates to be at their best. With fewer expenses in school, less debt when they graduate, and less anxiety about financial support along the way, students of all ages will be better prepared to start their new career and climb the ladder to home ownership, or starting a family, or whatever their dreams and ambitions in life. https://www.facebook.com/WynneFans/

New Year’s is a time of reflection and change, so as we count down to 2018, I’m reflecting on all the change in our economy in 2017 and looking ahead, to the changes that we are making to build a province where no matter what happens in the global economy, families are able to get ahead. First on our list? Our commitment to help 100,000 more kids access quality child care. This is all about taking pressure off families and making sure that kids across the province can get high-quality care, and their parents can go back to work on their terms, with the confidence that their kids are getting the best possible start in life. https://www.facebook.com/WynneFans/

Merry Christmas, everyone! On Christmas I’m always especially grateful for my amazing family, supportive friends and my wonderful community. Regardless of whether or not you celebrate, I’m wishing you a safe, joyful day surrounded by your loved ones. Stay warm! https://www.facebook.com/WynneFans/
From my family to yours, Merry Christmas! Wishing you and your loved ones a relaxing, wonderful holiday. https://www.facebook.com/WynneFans/

Those first few years as a parent are stressful enough, learning new routines and getting to know your child. So it really concerns me when I speak to parents who are weighed down with the extra stress of not being able to find affordable, licensed child care. Even though they’re ready to go back to work, and need the income to support their families, some parents have to stay home or make huge sacrifices just to get their child the strong start they need. We have to do better. That’s why we’re committed to creating another 100,000 child care spaces in 5 years, so that families can access the high-quality care their kids need, and parents have the opportunity to go back to work. https://www.facebook.com/WynneFans/

We’ve all heard the stories of families who had to make the impossible choice between putting food on their table or paying their hydro bill. I’ve spoken to some of these families. I know it was not fair to them or to anyone. Especially this time of year, people shouldn't have to choose between keeping the lights on and putting food on the table. Ending coal, rebuilding the crumbling electricity system and cleaning our air were all the right things to do. Smog days are thankfully a thing of the past. But putting all the costs on today’s ratepayers wasn’t fair. The system we’ve built will benefit Ontario for generations to come. That’s why, starting in the summer, we cut hydro bills for everyone in Ontario by 25%, and we’re providing further relief for low-income families and those in rural areas. https://www.facebook.com/WynneFans/

High speed rail in countries around the world has proven that it cuts down on travel times, creates jobs and supports communities along the way. Not only that, but Ontario is growing, and we need to continue to build up transportation across the province to keep up with that growth. That’s why we’re committed to a full Environmental Assessment to build high speed rail along the Toronto-Windsor corridor.  As we move forward with the project, I’m looking forward to seeing the opportunity that high speed rail creates from Toronto to Windsor and in the innovative communities everywhere in between. https://www.facebook.com/WynneFans/

Some people have a particularly difficult time during the holidays. It’s heartbreaking to think of families who can’t afford to celebrate with their loved ones the way they’d like to. But the holidays are also a time for hope, because we know it doesn’t have to be this way. We know we can build a fairer, better Ontario for every family. And that’s why we launched  at a Basic Income pilot in 2017.Ontario’s economy is strong but that’s not necessarily translating into better or more opportunities. So this is the perfect time to take bold actions that change our province for the better. Our Basic Income pilot will help people who have fallen on hard times get back on their feet. It will allow them to go back to school, search for a job, pay for their basic necessities, and get the support they need. And then we’ll know if a basic income is a smarter, more successful way of supporting people who are in transition.We don’t have final results yet, but so far it’s clear that this change is helping people access opportunity and fairness that we all deserve. https://www.facebook.com/WynneFans/

Commuters tell me that they’re sick of being stuck in traffic every day. They need their trip to work every day to be reliable and affordable. At a time when our province is growing and people are travelling further from home to go to work every day, I get that. That’s why we’re cutting transfer fees between GO Transit and the TTC by 50%, so that your commute is faster, more convenient and more affordable. https://www.facebook.com/WynneFans/

Knowledge is power, so when some people can’t afford to go get an education, that’s a big problem. I believe that access to post-secondary education should be based completely on your potential, and not at all based on your ability to pay tuition. That’s why we’ve overhauled the Ontario Student Assistance Program. The new OSAP gives more students the chance to go to college or university — over 210,000 are receiving free tuition this school year for the first time ever, and for so many others grants are more generous than before. I have a plan to build a fairer, better Ontario and in a big way, it rests on every young person getting that chance to go to college or university, without graduating under a mountain of debt. Knowledge is power, so go ahead, apply for the new OSAP today! https://www.facebook.com/WynneFans/

One of the things I think about often is the health and well-being of my aging parents. At 89 and 91, I want to make sure they have all the support they need to age with confidence — and on their own terms. The action plan for seniors that we introduced this year focuses on the issues and areas that seniors have told me matter to them the most at this stage in their lives — like living independently for as long as they can, and staying active and connected to their community. We’re empowering seniors to make their own choices when it comes to their care, their independence, and how they access the government services they need. We’re also hugely expanding the number of long-term care beds throughout Ontario, and increasing staff and support for residents of long-term care homes, so that our loved ones have the best care possible. https://www.facebook.com/WynneFans/

It’s wintery out there right now but we love cycling here in Ontario. It’s a great form of exercise, a convenient way to get around and a wonderful opportunity to spend time with your family — and every time you bike instead of driving, you’re fighting climate change! As the way we get around changes, more and more people are hopping on their bikes to get where they need to go. It’s great, and we need to support it. That’s why we took action this year — more than doubling our investment — to make cycling safer and more convenient for families throughout Ontario. https://www.facebook.com/WynneFans/

Having grown up in Richmond Hill, I know how difficult the commute can be from the 905 into the city. It’s been a long time since I lived there, but I know the commute has only become more difficult. We’re building more transit options for commuters in the 905 and across Ontario. Today is a big day — the largest Toronto subway expansion in decades is now open to the public. To celebrate, all TTC rides today are free.I hear from people who deal with long commutes to work. They’re sick of being stuck in traffic, especially if it means arriving to work late, or getting home frustrated and tired. Six new stops from Toronto up to Vaughan are ready to get you where you need to be — and will make your trip faster, more reliable and more affordable.If you’re not in the Greater Toronto Area, we’re building transit to benefit you, too. That’s why we’re calling this new subway a milestone, not a finish line. We’ll continue building affordable transit throughout the province to help you get to work, class, and home to your family quickly and reliably. https://www.facebook.com/WynneFans/

We're celebrating the largest expansion of Toronto's subway system in nearly 40 years by making the TTC free on December 17, the first day of service for the new Line 1 extension into York Region. https://www.facebook.com/WynneFans/

I believe that everyone deserves a safe, affordable place to call home. This year, finding affordable housing became a serious concern for families all over Ontario. We listened, and we took action. Our plan has calmed the frenzy in the housing market and it’s increasing the supply of new homes to keep things calm. And because skyrocketing rent increases weren’t at all fair, we introduced rent control on all rental units throughout Ontario — no matter when a building was built.When you have an affordable roof over your head, the world is a different place. You’re able to go out and pursue new opportunities and focus on getting ahead. That’s an Ontario that’s fairer and better for all. https://www.facebook.com/WynneFans/

A huge change to health care for kids is coming on New Year’s Day. One of the most challenging things about our changing economy is the uncertainty it’s created for families. Benefits plans aren’t what they used to be, and parents can’t always afford insurance to get the support their families need. When circumstances change so drastically like this, I believe government has a responsibility to step up and provide some of the security that has slipped away. That’s why we’re launching OHIP+ on January 1st, 2018. Free prescription medication for everyone under 25 will help families get their kids the care that they need, at no cost. There’s no catch — all you need is a health card.I’m fighting for a national pharmacare program that will provide prescription drug coverage for people of all ages, and OHIP+ — the biggest expansion of Medicare in a generation — is a strong start. It’s creating a fairer, more secure Ontario for families. And it’s just one of the changes we’re making to build a fairer, better province with opportunity for everyone. https://www.facebook.com/WynneFans/

The largest expansion to Toronto’s subway in 40 years will be open to the public this Sunday! What an amazing day it will be. When I was a little girl (a long time ago!), my grandmother took me on the subway, which was new at that time. It was a special day — she made me wear white gloves for the occasion. I think there's something special about the possibilities new transit brings, and I got that same feeling at our announcement today. The six new stops that will open this weekend will get people to work, class and home to their families all the way from Vaughan to Toronto. Years in the making, Ontario contributed $974 million to the project. The opening of the Toronto York-Spadina subway extension means York University students can finally take the subway to class for the first time, and elementary school students can now take the subway on field trips to Pioneer Village. And not only that, as our province continues to grow, it will connect cities and regions through a fast, reliable and affordable new transit option.  This momentous day marks a huge milestone for transit in Ontario, but our investments won’t stop here. We’re keeping our shovels in the ground and look forward to celebrating many more big transit projects — from LRTs in Waterloo, Toronto and Ottawa, to Regional Express Rail along the Toronto-Windsor corridor — that will help people connect throughout Ontario. https://www.facebook.com/WynneFans/

This year has been about creating fairness and opportunity, so as we approach Christmas I want to highlight 12 things we’re doing to make Ontario more fair and to give families opportunity. First up, a huge, necessary change that is going to make a difference in millions of lives starting on January 1st . We’re increasing the minimum wage to $14 on New Year’s Day and to $15 on January 1st, 2019, because it is the right thing to do.  If you work full-time, you should be able to buy the groceries you need, pay your rent and support your family. But the reality is that I hear from people who not only work full-time, but juggle multiple jobs, and they still struggle to make ends meet. Some families, after a 40+ hour work week, have to rely on food banks to feed their kids.  On January 1, these families are going to wake up in a fairer, better Ontario. And making sure millions of people get the raise they deserve is just one way that Ontario is changing for the better on January 1st. Stay tuned for more! https://www.facebook.com/WynneFans/

Parents tell me that they're anxious about the future. When they look at today's economy, it looks different than it did when they were entering the job market. Students need to be prepared for the jobs that will be available to them in a rapidly changing, global economy. To help students prepare, we need to make sure that our courses, programs and skills training keep up. That's why we're adding financial and digital literacy to the Grade 10 career studies course next September. We're also expanding hands-on learning opportunities in the course to give students tangible experience. These changes will better equip students with the life skills they need to succeed. https://www.facebook.com/WynneFans/

The stress of finding affordable child care is driving parents to the brink. Raising your kids should be a wonderful, joyful experience, so when parents tell me about the difficult, stressful choices they’re making because they can’t find quality, affordable child care, I know something must be done. No parent should have to give up their career simply because of a lack of child care, and yet this is happening, especially to women. We’re never going to reach gender equality and close the pay gap if mothers are unable to work. None of this is okay.That’s why, this morning, we announced new child care spaces at nearly 200 schools throughout the province — so that 8,400 more kids can get the best start possible, and parents can return to work when they’re ready.  That may sound like a drop in the bucket, but it’s part of a plan to help 100,000 more 0-4 year-olds access child care over the next five years – and we’re well on our way. https://www.facebook.com/WynneFans/

Attending college or university should be about how much effort you put into your studies, not how much education you can afford. When you're a student, the fees add up fast — it might be the heftiest bill to pay, but tuition is just one of the costs you need to cover. That's why, in addition to free tuition for 210,000 students this fall through the new OSAP, we've taken action to make other parts of your education more affordable, too — including textbooks. We've made online textbooks free for students, so that you can focus on your studies. https://www.facebook.com/WynneFans/

The way people get around is changing — there are more cyclists on the roads than ever before. That’s why we’re doubling down on cycling infrastructure in communities throughout Ontario. Whether you bike to work or like to go for a ride with your family, we’re making it safer and more convenient for you and your loved ones to get around on your bike. https://www.facebook.com/WynneFans/

Ontario has the shortest health care wait times in Canada, according to a new study by the Fraser Institute. But the truth is the study also highlights just how much more work we have to do. I’ve heard from patients in the hospital, or waiting at home for an appointment, and I know from personal experience how stressful it can be for the whole family when you have to wait to see a doctor or start a medical treatment. That’s why we’re working to decrease wait times across the province. I’m not going to stop working to get you faster care, closer to home. Visit ontario.ca/waittimes to learn more about wait times in your community. https://www.facebook.com/WynneFans/

Today we mourn and remember the 14 smart women who were murdered in a senseless act of violence at L’École Polytechnique. Their young lives were taken in a place they loved, and a place they belonged — the classroom — just because they were women. 28 years later, I wish I could say that all women are treated with kindness and respect. But the chilling truth is that women are still at a greater risk of violence of harassment, and it happens in their homes, at work, and in public. This gender-based violence has touched all of our lives, and we need only look to the ever-growing claims of sexual harassment and violence in the news recently to see just how prevalent and heartbreaking it is.  And so, in memory of the 14 students at L’École Polytechnique, and every other victim of gender-based violence, today we recommit ourselves to ending violence against women and supporting all women who experience it. In Ontario we’re making progress — taking concrete steps like making it easier for women experiencing violence to break their lease and find free legal advice — but we need to do more, and quickly. We can’t stop until we’ve built a province and a society where everyone is safe and respected. https://www.facebook.com/WynneFans/

I want to hear from you! Last month I held a Town Hall where anyone could come and ask me anything. People showed up with fantastic, sometimes tough questions about the issues that affect them and their community. It was a great conversation. I’ll be holding another Town Hall next week — this time in Peel Region.     Like last time, no topic will be off the table. It’s important to me that I hear from the people of Ontario directly. That’s part of what government and my role as Premier are all about. In this economy of uncertainty and rapid change, we’re working to build an Ontario where everyone can get ahead. It’s unacceptable to me that the rich keep getting richer while others are being left behind.  So, I want to know what’s on your mind? What’s holding your family or your community back? I want to hear your ideas so that we can create opportunity and security for everyone. http://ontario.ca/townhall https://www.facebook.com/WynneFans/

Senator Bernie Sanders’ visit to Ontario hospitals busted key myths about our single-payer system. As Senator Sanders discovered – our health care system is world-class when it comes to innovation and excellent care. And our highly skilled healthcare professionals prove it every day when they put patients first, making sure you get the care you need — without worrying about the cost.   See what else Senator Sanders and his team of American healthcare professionals learned from Ontario patients and doctors about our universal healthcare system. https://www.facebook.com/WynneFans/

It was an honour to attend the 70th Sai Wan Remembrance Day ceremony this morning in Hong Kong. We gathered in solemn remembrance at the Sai Wan War Cemetery, as people have done for the past 70 years, to honour the soldiers who bravely fought to defend Hong Kong during WWII. The ceremony was an opportunity to give thanks for the unimaginable sacrifice our soldiers made. It was in Hong Kong that Canadian soldiers first entered battle in the Second World War, and 550 Canadian soldiers died here, in battle or captivity. On this very meaningful day, we honoured those who are no longer with us, our veterans, and those who continue to serve today. As we remember the lives lost to war and the sacrifices made by an entire generation, this important site is a reminder to always choose peace and diplomacy over bloodshed and war. We can’t repay those buried here for everything that their sacrifice has given us, but we can vow to uphold the values of democracy and the freedom that they fought so hard to defend. https://www.facebook.com/WynneFans/

It's powerful to see so many women coming together and using their collective voices to speak out against sexual violence. It takes courage to say #metoo and to push for the shift in attitudes and behaviours that is needed to make our society safer and more equal for all women. For too long, sexual harassment and violence against women have persisted in our world and change is overdue. https://www.facebook.com/WynneFans/

In just one month, 4,400 prescription drugs will be free in Ontario for everyone 24 and under through OHIP+. To help families prepare for this exciting change, we’ve created a new, mobile-friendly online search tool to check if the medication your child needs will be covered. It helps you quickly and easily search the list of more than 4,400 publicly funded medications and other drug products. Visit this page to try it out: https://www.ontario.ca/ohipplus The list includes asthma inhalers, drugs to treat depression, anxiety, epilepsy, and attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, antibiotics, EpiPens, diabetes test strips, oral contraceptives, medications to treat some childhood cancers and other rare conditions, and thousands of others. In this time of rapid economic change and uncertainty, our government is doing everything we can to make sure that families have the support they need to take care of their kids. And so, on January 1, 2018, we’re launching OHIP+ to provide free prescription medication for everyone up until their 25th birthday. Enrollment will be automatic and prescriptions can be filled free of charge at any Ontario pharmacy – all that’s needed is a health card. https://www.facebook.com/WynneFans/

Today we learned that our unemployment rate is the lowest it's been in 17 years, and that Ontario added another 43,500 jobs in November. That means there are 180,000 more jobs in Ontario today than there were last year at this time. It’s great news, but I know it isn’t good enough. I know there are still so many who see these numbers and ask how it is possible that in a growing economy like this, they’re still falling behind.  In your Facebook comments, in your tweets, and when I meet you in your community, I hear about the real challenges you’re facing in our changing economy. The trouble finding affordable child care. The struggle to save for retirement. The growing commute. The shrinking sense of security. It all adds up to the reality that growth just isn’t doing what it used to. We need to find new ways of making sure that growth benefits everyone, and that’s exactly what our plan for a fairer, better Ontario is about. Raising the minimum wage, providing free tuition and free prescriptions for children and youth, creating 100,000 child care spots… these are the steps we’re taking to build an economy where everyone has a fair shot at getting ahead. An economy where growth isn’t just a number in the news, but is something that means more opportunity and more security for you and your family.  Today’s job numbers tell us that we’re on the right track, and we absolutely need to keep going. https://www.facebook.com/WynneFans/

This week someone asked a question on my Facebook page about supports for students in Ontario, who have good grades but don't have the money to go to college or university. I was happy to be able to respond that we've taken major steps to make pursuing a post-secondary education more affordable. In fact, this fall 210,000 Ontario students received free tuition, and more received grants that will help them graduate with less debt.I believe attending college or university should be about a student's potential, not what they or their parents can afford. Applications for next year are now open — earlier than ever before. See how much assistance you'll qualify for and apply: http://ontario.ca/osap https://www.facebook.com/WynneFans/

I'm grateful to these Hamilton residents for sharing their experiences on our basic income pilot. "I've never been better after 14 years of living in poverty," said Dave Cherkewski, a 46-year-old in Hamilton. He says the extra $750 a month he receives as part of our basic income pilot has eased the stress and mental illness that kept him out of work since 2002. Tim Button, another Hamilton participant, shared a similar sentiment. "It's making a huge difference for me," he told the Associated Press. Adding that an almost 60% increase in benefits through the pilot has helped decrease his depression, allowed him to schedule a long-postponed trip to the dentist, eat healthier & make plans to visit distant family over the holidays for the first time in years. I know that in our uncertain economy, people are falling behind, and that means as a government, we have to do everything we can to give people more opportunity to get ahead and to make our province fairer. Our basic income pilot is making a positive difference. These personal stories show that, with a basic income, people can lift themselves up. https://www.facebook.com/WynneFans/

Earlier this week a senior left a comment on my Facebook page sharing the challenge he faces paying for the cost of rent. I know seniors, especially those on a fixed income, face real challenges with increasing costs. I'm taking action to make life more affordable for seniors and all renters across Ontario. We all need a safe, affordable place to call home. I've heard from seniors who had to scramble to find a new place to live when their rent suddenly skyrocketed and was impossible for them to afford. That's not fair, it's not right, and it's time for government to step up and do something about it. Everyone deserves assurance that a sudden, dramatic change in rent isn't going to leave them without a roof over their heads. That's why we're protecting renters by capping annual rent increases to 2.5% — no matter when their home was built. https://www.facebook.com/WynneFans/

Common Ground Discussion - Community Resilience - Panelists:Chris Ballard, Minister of Environment and Climate ChangeMayor Bonnie Crombie, Mayor of MississaugaJulia Langer, CEO, The Atmospheric FundLaura Zizzo, Founder & CEO, Zizzo StrategyShare your ideas, interests and expertise and they might make it into our 2018 election platform. http://commonground.ontarioliberal.ca/ https://www.facebook.com/WynneFans/

In the face of climate change and the rapidly changing economy, how can we make sure our communities are prepared for the future? This is a question I hear a lot from families and workers throughout Ontario. That's why we're making the biggest investment in infrastructure in our province's history. We're working to make sure that every community - from the smallest town to the biggest city - has the infrastructure needed to not just be livable, but to be sustainable, resilient and vibrant no matter what the future holds.Join Minister of the Environment and Climate Change Chris Ballard, Mayor Bonnie Crombie, Julia Langer and Laura Zizzo at 6:30 PM this evening for a live panel discussion on community resilience, and then head over to the Common Ground website to share and discuss ideas. http://commonground.ontarioliberal.ca/ https://www.facebook.com/WynneFans/

This week we guaranteed a fair, living wage for everyone. But that’s not all Bill 148 will do to make sure Ontario workers are treated fairly.It’s a fact of life that sometimes emergencies will crop up when we least expect them. And when they do, everyone should be able to get the time off they need to support their family. Under the old rules, some workers didn’t have that freedom. And that wasn't fair. We passed a law to make sure that all workers have at least two days of paid emergency leave a year. This law will also raise the minimum wage to $15/hour on January 1, 2019, make sure that part-time workers are getting paid equally for doing the same work as their full-time colleagues, increase vacation time, ensure reliable scheduling and regulate being on call. These changes are the right thing to do as we build a fairer, better Ontario. https://www.facebook.com/WynneFans/

When I hear from people who deal with long commutes, they tell me that they need their trip to be reliable and affordable. They’re sick of being stuck in traffic, arriving to work late or getting home tired and frustrated. I get that. That’s why we’re making the biggest investment in infrastructure in Ontario’s history. Your commute should be as quick and seamless as possible, and we’re working on it. We're also working to keep your costs down. For people transferring between GO transit and the TTC, transfer fees are about to be cut by 50%. If you make that transfer every day, those savings are going to add up to about $720 a year. Our communities are growing because people want to live and work here. It's my job to build the roads and transit that make that growth a good thing, not a headache. And it's a job I take very seriously. https://www.facebook.com/WynneFans/

I’m travelling on a trade mission in China and Vietnam to promote Ontario as one of the best, most competitive places in the world to do business and invest. This is my third mission to China as Premier, and I’m confident that strengthening our international ties will create jobs and opportunity at home. I’m kicking off the mission in Beijing, where one of the highlights of my first day was a fireside chat on women and leadership. We discussed how to support female entrepreneurs in China and at home in Ontario, how to improve women’s economic empowerment and how we can all take further steps towards equality around the world. Over the next two weeks, I’ll meet with business and political leaders to strengthen Ontario’s already strong trade and innovation partnerships and identify new opportunities for collaboration. Just today, I announced almost $600 million in new agreements signed by Ontario and Chinese businesses and institutions that will fuel innovation, create good jobs and help businesses stay competitive in a global, rapidly changing economy. I look forward to working with Ontario delegates on this trip as they connect with international partners to grow their business, create good jobs and seek new opportunities that benefit people across our province. https://www.facebook.com/WynneFans/

People in Ontario live very busy lives. They need to be able to get to school, work and other activities with ease, whether they walk, cycle, take transit or drive. In all of our diverse communities, from the smallest villages to the biggest cities, how can we make them more sustainable, livable and vibrant? How can we ensure that our communities have the infrastructure they need to be resilient in the face of climate change and a rapidly changing economy?Join Minister of the Environment and Climate Change, the Hon. Chris Ballard MPP, as he explores these questions with a panel of experts. And then head to Common Ground to share your ideas and discuss other ideas! https://www.facebook.com/WynneFans/

People have told me they can't remember the last time a sitting Premier of Ontario held an event where anyone could come and ask anything they want. We changed that on Monday, I’m happy to say.Thank you to everyone for your questions at the first in a series of public Town Halls I’m hosting! From the college strike to cannabis, child care, the minimum wage and everything in between, no topic was off the table. That was the whole point of this Town Hall — and it’s why I’m eager to hold another one soon to keep the conversation going. Stay tuned for details! https://www.facebook.com/WynneFans/

This is why I'm in politics. This morning, we passed the law that officially raises the minimum hourly wage to $15 by January 1, 2019. We are guaranteeing a fair, living wage for everyone who works hard in Ontario, and requiring employers to give workers the fair scheduling, emergency leave, equal pay for part-time workers, and paid vacation we all deserve. I've met people who work full-time or juggle multiple part-time jobs at the minimum wage, and it's just not enough to support themselves and their family. That is never fair, especially in an economy where the rich are getting richer. In this time of uncertainty for so many, I have a responsibility to take action. Raising the minimum wage is the right thing to do to build a fairer, better province for everyone. And fighting for fairness is what I signed up for. https://www.facebook.com/WynneFans/

Introducing Dr. Molly Shoichet, Ontario’s first ever Chief Scientist! Our world is changing so quickly, and as we tackle some of the greatest challenges of our time — like climate change — it’s undeniable that science needs to play an increasingly important role. Science is about the discovery of truth, and governments who choose to be informed by objective, scientific truths make better decisions than those who blindly follow ideologies or assumptions.Dr. Shoichet is an internationally respected and award-winning scientist and I’m looking forward to her advice on how the world’s best scientific research and evidence can make our government smarter and more effective in getting you the services you need.Scientists right here in Ontario are doing amazing research. At a time when some are turning their backs on science, we’re committed to investing in and promoting the work of our remarkable scientists. I’m excited to see how Dr. Shoichet will strengthen the research and innovation happening across our province. https://www.facebook.com/WynneFans/

Students have been in the middle of the college strike for too long. Today we introduced legislation that would end the college labour dispute and return students at Ontario's 24 colleges to the classroom as soon as possible.We've also instructed colleges to establish a dedicated fund with all savings from the strike. The fund will be used to support students who have experienced financial hardships as a result of the strike and, most importantly, it will be developed in direct consultation with students. https://www.facebook.com/WynneFans/

Earlier this week I talked to a young woman who has spent time in foster care, in group homes, and in the shelter system. It was so important to me to hear from this young woman. Against impossible odds, she did everything right and still couldn't afford to stay in school. And she told me about people she knows who are working two minimum wage jobs and still can't pay the bills.  But she hasn't lost hope. She is getting the support she needs to go back to school next year and go after her dreams. When I think about some of the things that we're doing as a government, I think about people like her - people who just can't get ahead and are on the edge of losing hope. It is frightening to think that there entire communities who are not getting a fair deal in our economy, places where hope is fading. That's really scary. And it's wrong. The things I'm doing as Premier are about building an economy where everyone can feel hopeful about the future, because they know they can get the education they need, because there are good opportunities out there, because a minimum wage job pays a decent wage, a fair wage, enough to get by. In an economy where the rich are getting richer, it is just wrong to me that there are millions of hard-working people falling behind. They deserve a raise. On January 1st, that's what they'll get. https://www.facebook.com/WynneFans/

Yesterday, Charles Sousa released Ontario’s Fall Economic Statement, or FES. FES is a mid-year check-in on our finances, how our economy is doing, and how we’re doing on the commitments we made to you in the 2017 spring Budget. Since we tabled this year’s Budget, I’ve spent time in communities throughout the province. One thing people tell me no matter where I am, both in person and online, is that they’re having a hard time today, and feeling even more uncertain about the future. The rising cost of living is a real challenge. But government can help — that’s what government exists to do. And with our balanced Budget, we’re not missing this opportunity to build greater fairness across the province. We are strengthening the key public services that matter most and doing things that will make everyday life fairer and more affordable. I’ve talked about some of the things we’re doing quite often here on my Facebook page. Things like raising the minimum wage to $15 an hour by January 1, 2019, and launching OHIP+ on January 1, 2018, which will provide free prescription drug coverage to everyone under 25 — all you need is a health card. We transformed OSAP to help students of all ages pursue their dreams. With our changes, 210,000+ students received free tuition this fall for the first time ever, and many more saw an increase in grants and were able to take on less debt. Applications are now open for students to apply for support for the 2018-2019 school year. Something you might not have heard as much about is what we’re doing to support seniors. I know that’s something I think about a lot — my parents are 89 and 91. Last week we announced that we’re creating more than 30,000 new long-term care beds over the next decade, and providing more supports so seniors can live independent, active and socially connected lives. For those on the other end of the spectrum, who are just starting out in their careers, we’re taking action so that they can get their foot in the door and get ahead in our quickly changing economy. We’re encouraging skills development and training through programs like the Graduated Apprenticeship Grant for Employers, and we’re providing new incentives to small businesses that hire young workers. From working parents, I’ve heard that it can be difficult to find quality, affordable child care. As part of our commitment to provide 100,000 new spaces, we’ve helped 24,000 more children access licensed child care this year. Waitlists aren’t gone yet, but they’re getting shorter and we’re going to keep going. So, what does FES really have to do with you? Well, if you feel like things are not as fair as they used to be, like the rules have changed under your feet, or you’re just fed up with the constant struggle to keep your head above water, FES is reassurance that your government is listening and taking action. We have a comprehensive plan to create fairness and opportunity during these turbulent times. We know that we can do better for you, and we’re not going to give up trying. https://www.facebook.com/WynneFans/

For several years now, my way of marking Remembrance Day has included a visit with veterans and their families at the Sunnybrook Veterans Centre in my community. It’s the largest veterans’ care facility in Canada — hundreds of men and women who served in the Second World War and in Korea live there.People like Francess Halpenny, who left her job at the University of Toronto and joined the women’s division of the Air Force in 1941 because, as she says, it felt like the right thing to do — people’s lives depended on it. And people like William Bacon, who goes by Bubba. Bubba was just 24 years old when his unit was one of the first to land on Juno Beach for that fateful D-Day invasion, which eventually lead to the liberation of Europe. I am grateful for the opportunity to say thank you, and to share their stories with everyone who came to Queen’s Park for our annual Ceremony of Remembrance.The sacrifices that our fallen soldiers, veterans and their families have made are more immense than most of us will ever know. But we must try. Because every one of their stories is a powerful reminder that we must do all we can to resolve conflict with diplomacy and peacemaking, not bloodshed and anguish. We owe everything to our veterans and all they ask is that we never, ever forget the sacrifice of their fallen brothers and sisters. We must never take for granted that our freedom was won by the horrors they faced in war — the sacrifice of so many young lives — the shattering of so many families. Lest We Forget. https://www.facebook.com/WynneFans/

I hear from seniors in letters, at retirement homes, in communities across the province, and I've heard from many people over social media, asking me what we’re doing to support seniors. They tell me that seniors want the freedom to make decisions about their care, independence, and how they access services. And I know exactly what they're talking about - my parents want the same things!Some retirement communities spring up naturally, as seniors move into an area or an already bustling neighbourhood ages on its own. These seniors don’t want to move into a retirement home — and they should have choices. If you’re happy where you are, we should support you where you are. That just makes sense.As part of our new plan for seniors we’re investing more than $15 million over two years in apartment buildings or housing developments where many seniors already live close to one another. These aren't retirement homes, but with a few key services and supports they could work way better for the seniors who live there. It's about giving seniors the support they need to age with confidence right at home in their own community. https://www.facebook.com/WynneFans/

They create innovative opportunities here in Ontario. I'll be travelling to China and Vietnam later this month with over 100 delegates, and I can't wait to see the opportunities and partnerships that grow out of this mission. ‎ https://www.facebook.com/WynneFans/

This morning I had the pleasure of meeting Kathy and Ananya, two first year students at McMaster. They had returned to their old high school in Mississauga to encourage their fellow students to apply for OSAP. I hope their stories will encourage you to apply, too. The changes we've made to OSAP mean both girls can pursue their dreams — and focus on their education, not their worry over how they'll afford it. In fact, thanks to the new OSAP, more than 210,000 students across Ontario are receiving free tuition this year for the first time ever. We've also made changes that give students more breathing room after they graduate before they need to start paying back their loans.  Deciding what you want to do after you graduate from high school is a big deal. That's why we've opened OSAP applications four months earlier than usual. Last week I met a Mom named Kim. Thinking your next car will be electric? Cobalt, Ontario hopes so. An anticipated surge in demand for cobalt is breathing new life into the town. On a search for new sources of the metal — a component in batteries used to power electric cars — automakers like Tesla found just what they were looking for in this Ontario town of only 1,100.It’s no secret that our economy is changing. One of the biggest challenges is that growth and opportunities are increasingly gravitating to the Ottawa and Toronto areas. As we work to make sure every part of the province can benefit from Ontario’s growth, it’s encouraging to see a huge opportunity like this for a northeastern town. I know our workers are ready to take on the challenge. https://www.bloomberg.com/news/features/2017-10-31/the-canadian-ghost-town-that-tesla-is-bringing-back-to-life https://www.facebook.com/WynneFans/

Health care in Ontario still needs work, and as I told Senator Bernie Sanders last weekend, we aren’t shying away from the challenge — we’re tackling it head-on. In just 2 months, you’ll see the biggest expansion of medicare in a generation.  Starting January 1st, 2018, your child’s health card is all you will need to fill their prescription medications for free anywhere in Ontario. No copay, no strings — 100% free prescription drugs for everyone in Ontario up until their 25th birthday.As our economy changes, I have heard from families who have lost their benefits or never had any to begin with. I have heard from young people who are struggling to get their career started after graduating. And I have said all along that we can and must do more to support people and save them money, especially in these uncertain times.Our health care system isn’t perfect, but it is getting better every day. And OHIP+ is a huge step forward. The next step is to keep working with my fellow premiers to get a universal pharmacare program that covers adults as well, because I believe everyone in Ontario should be able to access the medicines they need to stay healthy. And I know we will get there.https://www.nytimes.com/2017/11/02/upshot/bernie-sanders-went-to-canada-and-learned-a-few-things.html https://www.facebook.com/WynneFans/

Ontario added jobs in October for the 4th straight month, but I know from talking to workers that for some, these are just numbers they hear on the news, not change they're seeing in their own community. The Fraser Institute backs that experience up with numbers, too - according to the report they released this week, Ontario's recovery from the recession has been extremely uneven, and most of the new jobs we've seen since 2008 have been in Toronto and Ottawa. That's why I'm taking action. Increasing the minimum wage will make this growth fairer so everyone across the province can benefit. We're also expanding emergency leave to a minimum a two paid days, and making sure that employees who work for the same company for 5 years get at least 3 weeks' vacation. When we all get the opportunity to be a part of Ontario's growth, everyone benefits. https://www.facebook.com/WynneFans/

Part-time and temporary workers deserve to be treated fairly. I've traveled all over the province over this year to sit down with workers and hear their experiences. One thing I hear time and again is that part-time, temporary and contract workers are working just as hard as their full-time colleagues, but they are being paid less - even though they're doing the same job. That just isn't fair. I've heard you, and I'm taking action to change this. Our plan makes sure that ALL workers are treated fairly. We're making it illegal to pay part-time or contract workers less than full-time workers for doing the same work because everyone deserves a fair shot at getting ahead. https://www.facebook.com/WynneFans/

Join us for the launch of Common Ground, our grassroots policy consultation, featuring a keynote and live panel discussion on the economy. In the face of challenges like globalization, automation and climate change government must take an active role in ensuring fairness and opportunity for everyone.Premier Kathleen Wynne will engage in a live discussion with panelists and an online audience across Ontario about how to respond to the changes people are experiencing in our economy and society. https://www.facebook.com/WynneFans/

This weekend at my nomination I met Basil, Maria, and A.J. in my community of Don Valley West. They all had thoughts to share about the change they want to see in their community - where free tuition is making their education more affordable, and programs are supporting children and residents. They want to live in a fair community and province. These are the diverse voices I'm representing - and the voices that push me forward in fighting for fairness. As our communities and our economy changes, I believe that everyone deserves to benefit from economic growth - and, in the highly skilled, globally competitive economy we're building, we need everyone to be a part of it. We've all seen what the changing global economy can mean — less security, reduced benefits, more part-time, minimum wage work and growing inequality. And we don’t have to look very far to see how quickly the gains we’ve won in the past to make our society fairer and kinder can be challenged, or even dismantled. Those things are happening as we speak. Those are real risks.That's why my plan meets these challenges head on. It increases the minimum wage to $14 an hour on January 1st and $15 one year later. It makes it illegal to pay part-time or contract workers less than full-time workers for doing the same work. And it gives everyone the right to vacation and paid sick days. In the public health care system, we’re creating fairness for every family with OHIP+,  a universal pharmacare program for everyone under the age of 25. In education and child care, we’ve delivered Full-Day Kindergarten and now we’re creating 100,000 more child care spaces. It isn’t fair that some families can find child care and others are left scrambling. We’re fixing that.  And under our plan, college and university tuition is free for 210,000 students starting this school year. https://www.facebook.com/WynneFans/

In Ontario and Canada we have health care that we can be proud of and over the weekend, I was proud to show our health care system to Senator Bernie Sanders. But there is more work to do to build an economy where everyone has a fair shot at supporting themselves and their families, things like making sure everyone is paid a fair wage.  Today I was listening to workers at The Irv Gastro Pub to hear from the people who will be affected by the changes we’re making. There is a true family vibe in the restaurant — it was started in memory of owner Regan’s father— and the respect that Regan and Jaclyn have for their employees in so clear. They’ve been paying their employees fair wages for years, and they say the difference it makes in their workplace is huge. One of their staff members even says she loves her jobs several times a day!  I heard from the pub’s staff that being paid a fair wage gives them the ability and flexibility to take care of themselves and work towards their goals. Alyssa is able to pursue her goal of becoming a firefighter while working at the pub, and Natasha is able to study to become a social worker. The staff couldn’t imagine how anyone is able to support themselves and their families on the current minimum wage.  I’m confident that raising it to $15 by January 1, 2019, is the right thing to do to build a fair economy for everyone. https://www.facebook.com/WynneFans/
